DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1994

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 24 March, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have before us the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 1994. There were three amending bills last year which set the foundations and amended the ATSIC arrangements so that there was an election in December. The Senate gave quite a deal of attention to these amendments and most of them have already been put in place.

PARA.TAB: But one area of the amendments to the legislation that we dealt with last year affects the Torres Strait regional authority which will come into effect on 1 July this year. In the months now leading up to 1 July the government has seen fit, after consultations with the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission, the Torres Strait Islanders themselves, and the opposition to bring in some further amendments before 1 July so that the Torres Strait regional authority is in its best definition before it begins to operate. Accordingly, we have in the bill before us some 10 or 11 pages of further amendments that almost entirely relate to a more careful definition of the Torres Strait regional authority.

The bill extends powers to the authority. It makes it more powerful and more capable to act independently as an authority. For example, it enables the Prime Minister to confer a departmental function on the Torres Strait regional authority. It enables a minister to confer commission functions—that is ATSIC—and other like powers. It gives authority for the regional authority to make agreements with other government bodies at all three levels of government and to make grants and loans to Queensland and its authorities, particularly local government authorities. It also allows the authority to use money in its land and resources fund, not only for acquiring land but to implement the marine strategy that is in the Torres Strait development plan. This bill also allows the minister to make rules for the conduct of elections by a system of wards in all or part of the Torres Strait area and it makes various minor administrative changes.

The opposition has long supported the idea of a distinct regional authority for the Torres Strait Islanders and it has long accepted a particular specific approach to what will best serve the interests of Torres Strait Islanders. We wish to be, as in the past, responsive to the representatives—indeed all of the people—of the Torres Strait in the determination of these matters. We are confident that the matters that are before us now enhance the best interests of the peoples of the Torres Strait and, accordingly, we have no objection to the bill. Indeed, we support these amendments to the ATSIC act.

We are also aware that, in addition to the provisions in the bill, there will be some final amendments that the government will introduce at the committee stage. These have been discussed with the Liberal and National parties. Whilst they will be more precisely explained by the minister in due course in this debate, I foreshadow that, as they have been explained to us up to this point, we accept the need for those further and final amendments to this bill.

With regard to the Torres Strait Islands' distinctiveness, the Aboriginal people of Australia recognise that there are Australian Aboriginal communities and there are the Torres Strait Island communities. There is full recognition of the distinctiveness of the Torres Strait Islanders as a part of Queensland and as a part of all of Australia, but as, nevertheless, a distinctive and separate region of this country. For example, the act refers to the first function of the Torres Strait regional authority as:

SPEECH.PARA: to recognise and maintain the special and unique Ailan Kastom of Torres Strait Islanders living in the Torres Strait area.

I take the words `Ailan Kastom' to be the pidgin—the language—used by the people to sum up the distinctive traditions and other customs which are special and unique to this region. The act notes that Ailan Kastom means:

the body of customs, traditions, observances and beliefs of some or all of the Torres Strait Islanders living in the Torres Strait area and includes any such customs, traditions, observations and beliefs relating to particular persons, areas, objects or relationships.

That is symbolised by our support of that inclusion in the act—the act is already a part of Australian law—and by our support of these enhancing measures in the bill before us. We support the recognition of the Torres Strait Islanders making a distinct community within Australia. Occasionally, separatists voices are raised with regard to the Torres Strait and the islands as a whole. I note that it is not the majority view of the Torres Strait Islanders to have any kind of separation or distinctiveness other than that which is provided for through the Torres Strait regional authority.

PARA.TAB: The majority of Torres Strait Islanders are proud to be Australians. That is the view of the Liberal and National parties. I understand that is very much the view of the Labor Party and the government. I have not heard voices from the wider community within Australia saying anything other than that the whole of the Torres Strait Islands is part of Queensland—and the whole of Queensland is part of Australia.

In all our decision making in this parliament I will continue to urge that we be mindful to provide for the regional authority within the Torres Strait so there is that self-determination at that level, and be so responsive in every other respect to all the people of Australia, including the Torres Strait Islanders, that we maintain the unity and wholehearted support of every individual within Australia for the unity of Australia. The government has foreshadowed that it will move two or three amendments and we will debate them at the committee stage if necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kernot Sen C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator KERNOT
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I too wish to speak to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 1994 which the Australian Democrats will be supporting. We agree that the bill plays an important part in the wider process of self-determination, in this case for Torres Strait Islander people. As Senator Teague has explained, it allows the Prime Minister to confer a departmental function and other functions previously exercised by the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission on the Torres Strait Islander Authority.

PARA.TAB: Former senator Michael Macklin was reminding me a few moments ago that he had suggested this structure be in place from the beginning. He is finding it quite interesting being here today and seeing this happening. These new powers include the right to grant loans and make agreements with the state government and its authorities, to spend money on land maintenance and acquisition, to implement the Torres Strait marine strategy, and to conduct elections.

The establishment of the Torres Strait Islander Authority is one outcome of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's review of its operations in 1993. That review identified the need to recognise Torres Strait Islanders as a distinct and separate group of indigenous Australians. From July this year the Torres Strait Islander regional authority will have functions and powers substantially parallel to those of ATSIC in the Torres Strait region.

Changes in this bill grant increased autonomy to the authority and strengthen the authority's ability to preserve the cultural identity and integrity of Torres Strait Islanders. This is a unique body of customs, traditions, observances and beliefs of the Torres Strait Islanders which we acknowledge should be recognised and respected. Like the commission, the authority will have the power to negotiate, cooperate and enter into agreements with other Commonwealth bodies, and with state, territory and local government bodies.

Providing that it furthers the social, economic or cultural development of Torres Strait Islanders, or of Aboriginal people in the Torres Strait area, the authority will be able to make grants and loans to the state of Queensland and its authorities. This is particularly important in ensuring that the authority can financially service its regional councils, which we were told was previously unclear under the review.

Currently, the money in the authority's land and natural resources fund can be used for acquiring an interest in land. Quite rightly, it is felt that this focus on land overlooks the unique connection that Torres Strait Islanders have with the sea and marine environment. I am a member of the Council for Reconciliation and in our vision statement we have a reference to the attachment to land and sea. I am particularly indebted to Mr Alan Mosby and Mr Bill Lowah for their articulate championing and explanation of the attachment indigenous people feel for the land, in the case of Aboriginal people, and to the sea for the Torres Strait Islanders.

In the past, our legislation has not specifically recognised this distinction. Proposed section 144W will take this into account. Use of money will be extended to include the development and implementation of the marine strategy in the Torres Strait development plan, the development and maintenance of real estate and the acquisition of land. This change facilitates the implementation of `a comprehensive conservation and sustainable development strategy' in the region as called for by the Torres Strait Islanders in 1991 in their Principles and objectives for the future of the Torres Strait.

The urgent need for localised coordination and management structure within the Torres Strait region was also endorsed in Towards a marine strategy for the Torres Strait in 1993. This bill today will assist this process. To understand the need of Torres Strait Islanders to organise autonomously also requires an understanding that their relationship with the sea is the fundamental part of their culture, traditional economy and activities. It is crucial that Torres Strait Islanders have authority over these areas of land and sea, as well as authority over themselves.

This bill and the supplementary amendments also outline the process for authority elections. While the changes to elections are mainly administrative, the additional amendments still allow for extra members to the authority, but set a maximum of 23. Other changes relate to zone and other elections, including the division of wards, determination of boundaries and the number to be elected in each ward. This is all part of the important process of self-determination for Torres Strait Islander people. I take the opportunity to congratulate those who have been elected in the recent Torres Strait Regional Council Commissioner and office holder elections: the new Commissioner, Mr Joseph Elu; the Chairperson, Mr Getano Lui Jr; the Deputy Chairperson, Mr Terry Waia; and the Alternate Deputy, Ms Romina Fujii.
I commend the changes in this bill to the Senate. The changes are those which the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commission's report appropriately summarises as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: The recognition of the deep and distinctive connection of the Torres Strait Islander people with their land and seas and their desire in goodwill and co-operation with others, to care for, sustain and develop their traditional estate presents no threat. . . It could be the catalyst for distinct gains.

Looking down this speakers list, I rather suspect that we are going to hear something on Aboriginal health from Senator Herron. Some speakers may refer to yesterday's Sunday program. I want to make a couple of comments in anticipation. Yesterday's Sunday program on ATSIC was a little one-sided. It was certainly put together by a well-intentioned journalist who shares with many people the frustration of what seems to be the pace of delivery of services at the community level in Aboriginal communities.

PARA.TAB: However, I do not think the program made the point sufficiently well—a point which I have made here so many times and which needs to be repeated: ATSIC is four years old. Why would we impose on one society of people the assumption and the expectation that they should be monolithic—that they should have one political view? Why would we not expect and allow a difference of opinion over the best way to deliver an outcome? Why would we expect that, in four years, ATSIC would be able, with the best will in the world and on the budget it has, to make up for 200 years—certainly 100 years—of mismanagement and lack of cooperation which sometimes our federal system is characterised by?

I hope that this bill will not turn into a focus for an attack on ATSIC. It has an incredibly difficult job, and nobody is saying that it does it perfectly. This bill is a result of an important review, and this next step forward in recognising the autonomy of the Torres Strait Islander people certainly has the support of the Democrats.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in support of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 1994 and all the amendments that are thereto attached. My involvement with the Torres Strait and the Torres Strait Islanders goes back some considerable time to 1983, when I was first elected and went to the Torres Strait on a Senate inquiry. I got to know the people. I was also on the original Senate inquiry that investigated ATSIC. In those days I fought in the parliament to have the Torres Strait Islanders and all their islands and their communities on the mainland incorporated into their own particular region for the very reason that they were a different race of people with different cultural expectations, and they wanted to protect those differences.

PARA.TAB: The amendments in this bill are only an advancement or a further step in the amendment that was originally moved, either by myself or by Senator Baume, when we drew a region around all the island communities and the mainland communities of Seisia and Bamaga and allowed them to have their own regional council. Even then, that regional council was administered by ATSIC. Those communities became a minority of a minority. It was always their concern. Now, with the establishment of this bill and last year's Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill (No. 3), they have gone a long way to their own self-determination.

I suggest that the Torres Strait Islands and the islanders who live on them have much more autonomy than the people of Christmas Island or Cocos Island. I know they are very vocal on some occasions in seeking what they call independence, but I believe what they are saying is that they want the Torres Strait Islands to be considered as a territory. I have pointed out to them from time to time that they have more autonomy than the Malays on Cocos Island and on Christmas Island, which are territories. I want the Torres Strait Islanders to consider that.

The implementation of the authority is based on the recommendations contained in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission's report on the review of the operations of the 1989 ATSIC Act. The other recommendations in the report relating to streamlining zone election rules are also dealt with in this bill. The main provisions of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 1994 allow the Prime Minister to confer a departmental function on the Torres Strait regional authority—to confer ATSIC functions on the authority. I suppose this will mean that the authority will be a mini-ATSIC, with the same powers and responsibilities as ATSIC. It has taken since 1989 for this to come about. I congratulate those communities on their perseverance in pursuing this matter; but it is a matter that, I believe, receives support from all senators of all parties in this chamber.

Other main provisions of this bill include: the authority to have power to negotiate, cooperate and enter into agreements with other Commonwealth bodies and with state, territory and local government bodies, and to make grants and loans to the state of Queensland and its authorities, including the local government; the expansion of the Torres Strait regional authority land and resources fund; and the minister to consult and make rules for the conduct of elections in the Torres Strait area by a system of wards.

I know now that there is also a state-run island coordinating council that has been the main avenue for people from the various islands who are elected at local government elections every three years under the Queensland local government legislation. The chairmen of those island councils form the island coordinating council. So we are now going to have an island coordinating council as well as this new authority that will be responsible for administering federal issues. I see some sort of a conflict there. It may be not so much a conflict as two bodies doing different things. Maybe in the future they can be brought together. I think that is one of the islanders' aspirations.

I have spoken to the islanders. I rang them and asked them whether they had any problems with the bill. They said that it has their support and that they look forward to its implementation. They are particularly keen to get it going right. They say that they have now been given the opportunity to run their own affairs. They are particularly keen to make sure that they make a total success of running this authority. They will know that the eyes of the media and the parliament will be upon them.

They told me today that they want to take it pretty slowly before they do anything other than bring the island coordinating council and the new authority together. They are also well aware of the responsibilities that have been placed on them. They are very keen to make sure that they are accountable in all areas and that they are able to deliver the services that their constituents need. They asked me to raise in parliament their concern about the run-off from Ok Tedi mine running down the Fly River. The Marine Park Authority has been monitoring the Torres Strait areas for the impurities that they believe have run off, but has withdrawn its service. They asked me to express their fear that the run-off may be interfering with their fishing and prawning grounds in the Torres Strait. So I place their concern on record.

I also add my congratulations to those of other speakers. When ATSIC was established there were misgivings on the part of not only the federal government but also many Aboriginal and Islanders which they expressed to the Senate committee when we were taking evidence. A number of them believed that ATSIC would overrule their local communities and they were not particularly keen to go ahead with it. I think there are still some fears. The fact that the Islanders can now run their own ship has relieved them of the majority of their fears. I wish them all the best. I hope that they do a particularly good job of administering this new authority and hold their end up, do the right thing and make a very successful go of it, as I am sure they will.

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 4 May, on motion by Senator Faulkner:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Amendment Bill 1994 amends the act to enable the adjustment of interest rates applicable to the Defence Force home loans assistance scheme. The effect of the proposed amendments is as follows. First of all, clause 3 amends section 35 of the principal act by removing subclause 5.15 from its ambit, thereby removing the prohibition on amending that subclause. Once the prohibition has been removed, subclause 5.15 of the agreement, as contained in the schedule, can then be amended. That amendment remains subject to clause 20 of the agreement, which provides that any amendment to the agreement will have no effect unless it is confirmed in writing by the Commonwealth and the National Australia Bank.

PARA.TAB: The background to this is that it was announced in the May 1985 economic statement that members of the Defence Force who joined after 14 May 1985 would not be eligible for the then home loan subsidy scheme and that the Defence Services Homes Corporation would be sold. The Defence service homes mortgage portfolio was sold and the Westpac Banking Corporation, which now operates the Defence service homes scheme under the Department of Veterans' Affairs, became the scheme's lender. The new scheme to cover those no longer eligible under the scheme which was sold was to operate from May 1991 and was to be run by the National Australia Bank, which was awarded a 15-year franchise.

The new scheme simply provided a subsidy of 40 per cent of the interest charged on the loan provided. The scheme provided that the duration of the subsidy was to be related to the person's period of service. The scheme itself was administered by the Defence Housing Authority on behalf of the Department of Defence. The essential part of the scheme is the agreement between the Commonwealth and the National Australia Bank, which is contained in schedule 1 of the Defence Force (Home Loans Assistance) Act 1990.

Clause 5 of the agreement covers subsidised loans. Subclause 5.15 makes provision for the cancellation of the benchmark rates of interest to be used for the purpose of calculating the subsidy. Under the agreement the benchmark rate of interest is the lower of the rate offered by the National Australia Bank and the average of the rates offered by the five largest Australian banks. When the agreement was drawn up, special introductory rates for new loans, with interest rates fixed for a period of 12 months or less, were not contemplated. The agreement as currently drafted would apply the special introductory rates to all borrowers under the scheme, irrespective of whether they are new borrowers, and for as long as those rates are offered.

The Commonwealth and the National Australia Bank have agreed that subclause 5.15 of the agreement should be amended so that the special introductory rates would apply only for new borrowers and for the period that those rates are available to the public. The opposition supports the bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1994 is one that the coalition generally agrees with. It follows on from a customs tariff amendment bill that the Senate dealt with last week. On that occasion I raised matters of very great concern to me and other members of both houses of parliament on the question of airline safety. These tariff bills relate to increases in the excise on Avgas and Avtur, and the money is being raised to go towards the cost of air safety.

PARA.TAB: Air safety is something that we are all very greatly concerned about. Last week in the debate I raised the question of the administration by the Civil Aviation Authority of issues of air safety. It is worth repeating that there have been so many inquiries into air safety and the Civil Aviation Authority and we never seem to get anywhere. We seem to keep going around in circles, and still there are horrendous examples which come out of lapses in administration of air safety.

The bill proposes amendment to the Excise Tariff Act 1921 to incorporate in that act two excise tariff proposals. Excise tariff proposal No. 2 proposes a reduction in excise duty payable in respect of Avgas, and excise tariff proposal No. 3 proposes an increase in excise duty payable in respect of Avgas and Avtur. It is proposed to reduce the excise on Avgas from $0.25456 per litre to $0.2243 per litre, a reduction of 3.013 cents per litre effective from 1 July 1993. This reduction results from the final stage of the government's program of transferring Commonwealth owned aerodromes to the full local ownership program. In 1993-94, outlays of $4.1 million in maintenance grants and $2 million in subsidies will secure the transfer of all 11 remaining aerodromes and the civil areas of three defence aerodromes. That program is one that has been under way for some time and is in its final stages. It is one that has seen most of the local aerodromes around the nation taken over by local ownership, and that program is coming to a conclusion.

The reduction also results from changes in the cost recovery arrangements for the provision of firefighting services by the CAA and changes in the cost recovery arrangements by CAA in the provision of meteorological services by the Bureau of Meteorology. In future, both the firefighting and meteorological services will be directly charged to aircraft operators.

As the amount of excise duty required to fund the aerodromes and these two services is reduced, the rate of duty can also be reduced. A decrease of 1.013c per litre is attributable to the aerodrome transfer program, and the remaining 2c per litre is attributable to the firefighting and meteorological services. It is also proposed to increase the excise payable on Avgas to $0.2299 per litre—an increase of 0.264c per litre. The increase was announced in the 1993 budget and it is effectively backdated from 1 September 1993. It is to enable the CAA to recover part of its costs of the aviation safety regulation from the aviation industry and is the first stage in a program to phase in recovery of the industry's contribution to these costs.

The Liberal-National coalition will not oppose these measures. The reduction in the level of duty resulting from the changes to ALOP, firefighting services and meteorological services is unexceptional. The increases in the rate of duty on Avgas and the new duty imposed on Avtur to fund aviation safety are more controversial. These relate to a plan of cost recovery that I will not repeat because I spoke about it in the bill last week.

However, there is discontent within the aviation industry over the government's original proposal which resulted in that original proposal being withdrawn. Apparently, the general view in the aviation industry is that, given that the government is not prepared to meet the costs of setting safety standards and ensuring compliance and that the industry must meet half the costs of these services, the bill is a reasonable method of covering the industry's share.

I again raise in the parliament my real concern about matters of safety generally. I repeat: I have been concerned at the answers or non-answers that I have been given by the CAA to questions I have raised both on notice in this chamber and in estimates committees, and will be pursuing again in estimates committees. I again raise the absolute inability of this government, it appears, to answer questions within the 30-day time limit. There are a number of questions which I have on notice, the answers to which are now outside the 30-day limit.

It seems that the government will have to be forced, screaming and kicking, to answer those sorts of questions. Apparently, the government is not prepared to comply with the rules. We will have to move the formal procedures within the Senate to get the answers to those questions. So at this stage I will not delay the Senate any further. These matters of the CAA and air safety will have to be pursued at the appropriate time. I repeat: it is not the intention of the Liberal-National party coalition to oppose these measures currently before the Senate.(Quorum formed)

TALK.START.PARA: —Today the Senate is debating the Excise Tariff Amendment Bill 1994, which has three purposes: firstly, to reduce the rate of excise duty payable on aviation gasoline by 3.013c per litre from 1 July 1993; secondly, to increase the rate of excise duty on Avgas by 0.264c per litre from 1 September 1993; and, thirdly, to increase the rate of excise duty on aviation kerosene by 0.264c per litre from 1 September 1993. These amendments to the tariff schedules all represent a validation of changes which have already been implemented.

PARA.TAB: The background to these amendments is that the corresponding customs tariff increase has been covered by the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1994. They relate to cost recovery from the airlines for the Civil Aviation Authority's provision of fire safety and meteorological services to the industry. In its 1992 budget, the government announced that it would move to a fifty-fifty cost sharing formula with the industry, after protests from the industry about a policy of full cost recovery which was announced in the 1990-91 budget but never implemented.

The government's failure to get industry agreement to a cost sharing mechanism led to the adoption of an interim measure to recover some costs from the industry in the 1993-94 budget. This involved increasing the customs and excise on Avgas and Avtur as per the bill and levying a charge on domestic based aircraft used in international operations since these are exempt from the excise.

Referring to the first measure mentioned, the much larger decrease relates to savings being passed back to the industry from the aerodrome local ownership plan. This plan dates back to the 1950s when it was decided that it did not make sense for the Commonwealth to retain ownership of all the small airports around Australia. The plan led to the handover of airport ownership to local authorities, usually the local government authorities. To sweeten the deal, the Commonwealth usually undertook any necessary capital works to bring the airport up to the required standard and also undertook some ongoing cost sharing in some cases. The whole plan was speeded up in the mid-1980s with the Commonwealth making large one-off payments to the local authorities representing the notional discounted value of future costs that the Commonwealth would otherwise have borne.

As a result of this operation the Commonwealth now runs fewer than 100 aerodromes and has made resultant savings in recurrent costs. That is why it is now passing back this saving to industry as a reduction in Avgas excise.

The net effect of this bill, on the basis of the three purposes that I have outlined, is that there will be a net decrease in the tariff on aviation fuel. The Australian Democrats are concerned about the impact of tariff increases in aviation fuel on people in remote areas and that is a battle to be fought in the future. I would like the government to take note that we are concerned about that, and whatever cost sharing arrangements are arrived at by the government in the future in this area to cover the costs of providing safety and meteorological services should take into account that any across-the-board increases in the ultimate cost of aviation fuel will affect people in remote communities much more severely. I do not think that I need to detain the Senate any longer. The Australian Democrats will not oppose this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak in tonight's adjournment debate about the life of someone with whom I have had the privilege of sharing the last 14 or 15 years of my life. I refer to a great Western Australian Liberal, the Hon. Robert Gerald Pike, who passed away very suddenly very late on Anzac Day, 25 April. Along with hundreds of Western Australians, I had the privilege of attending Bob Pike's funeral on the Thursday before last, along with Bob's widow Patti and his seven children and many colleagues from both sides of politics. It was a very sad and solemn occasion, particularly as Bob was so active in political life in Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: He was a larger than life character for many reasons. When someone who had such a crucial role in the Western Australian Liberal Party and parliamentary politics in Western Australia is taken from this earth so quickly and unexpectedly in very much the prime of his life, it is a very sad occasion—particularly for those of us who were very close to Bob, as I was.

I wanted to take some of the time of the Senate tonight to reflect on some of Bob's contributions, some of the times that I personally spent with Bob, and some of the battles that we fought together. I hope the Senate will indulge me for some time while these remarks are put down in the Senate record.

It is quite appropriate, indeed, that Bob Pike have a tribute paid to him in the Senate because, above all the things that Bob was in his life, he was a very strong family man, a very successful businessman, a very successful person in local government and a very successful person in the lay organisation of the Liberal Party. One of the most driving elements in his political philosophy was that he was a strong federalist. He was a great supporter of views of the founding fathers as to how the federation should be formed. He was a great student of the history of federation, not only in Australia but also in the United States and Canada.

When the Liberal Party coalition won the last state election in Western Australia the Premier, Richard Court, appointed Bob Pike to have special responsibility for federal-state relations as a parliamentary secretary to the Premier. That is an area that the Premier is pursuing very strongly.

It is quite appropriate that Bob Pike have a tribute paid to him in the Senate because he was a great supporter of the institution of the Senate. Last week, as I was preparing some notes for this speech, I thought what a great senator Bob Pike would have made. One aspect of his life that many people did not know about was that he did not enjoy plane travel at all. I think he was a bit scared of plane travel, and if he had the choice between catching a plane across to the eastern states or getting on a train, he would always get on the train or drive his car. As Senator McMullan would know, one could not really be a senator from Western Australia if one had an aversion to aeroplane travel.

As I recall it, I met Bob Pike—I do not keep a diary as accurately as Mr Pike did—back in about 1981 or 1982, a year or so after I joined the young Liberal movement and the university liberal club. We were then lobbying the Court-O'Connor Liberal government on the voluntary student union legislation. At that time Bob was minister for sports and youth, as I recall, and he was a fairly active and influential member of the O'Connor government, as it was then. I was quite impressed by Mr Pike. Anyone who met him could not have failed to have at least left the room with some impression of him because he was a flamboyant character, an articulate character and a very likeable character. As a very keen, enthusiastic, if not ambitious young Liberal, I had a lot to do with Bob leading up to what was a very disastrous 1983 state election.

I was involved in the Whitford campaign in which we were very thoroughly beaten by Pam Beggs, who went on to become a minister after the election. I ran the Whitford campaign as chairman, and Bob, an upper house member at that time, was involved in the campaign as well. I recall going to a protest meeting at the Whitford Nodes and basically being a spy there on Pam Beggs and Brian Burke, as he then was, for Bob Pike. I attended the meeting and then I went to Bob's office at six o'clock the next morning and gave him a detailed report on what was said. Of course, what we said about the Whitford Nodes made no difference at all in that seat. It was a mortgage belt seat and it saw an enormous swing against us.

I worked very closely with Bob in that period. I quickly gained the impression that he was someone who was a very solid grassroots worker who had very good links with the organisation and treated the Liberal organisation with enormous respect. He was not one of those politicians who get elected to a seat in parliament, or to the upper house, and quickly forget those who endorsed them and put them into power. That was the theme of so much of Bob Pike's political career. He kept close links not only with the organisation, the branches and the divisions of the Liberal Party, but also with the community in a whole series of different ways.

The next interesting part of my life with Bob Pike was when Ian Medcalf MLC decided to retire from the parliament and left a vacancy in what I think was called the north metropolitan region. It was like a Senate casual vacancy; it was a walk-in into the parliament, so we had a Melbourne Cup field. I think 15 or 16 candidates decided they wanted to grace the benches of the upper house. I, as a 24-year-old who thought he knew how to change the world and fix all the problems of the world, decided to put up my hand for it. Bob Pike, having just lost his seat at the 1983 election, also decided that he wanted to walk into Meddy's seat. Of course, Max Evans, who was ultimately successful in the preselection, had nominated. Even Senator Ellison might have toyed with the idea at some stage, but he was probably wiser than me and did not stick up his hand at the time.

Bob was in the running. Even though I had had a bit to do with Bob, I was not close to him at that time. He was going around lobbying the people that I was lobbying. He was getting commitments from them, and so was I. It was quite a battle. It was friendly between Bob and me. In the end, Max Evans won the first preselection. As Senator Ellison will remember, I became aware at the preselection—I think there were 87 or 88 people entitled to vote—that a couple of people there who happened to be university Liberal club members were not actually entitled to be there. That was my understanding of the constitution. Even though I suspected very strongly that the university Liberals at the preselection would have voted for me, I also suspected that if Bob Pike and I worked together, if we had a re-run of the preselection, we might do better. So I had those university Liberals wiped off the preselection.

The interesting thing was that someone had to put in the appeal within the 48-hour cut-off period after the preselection. I was quite determined that I had been totally wronged by the process and quite determined that I would have this appeal. I thought it would be better politics if both Bob Pike and I put in the appeal, so that neither of us had the odium of being the appellant, overturning this preselection and upsetting 87 people who did not want to come out on a cold, dark night and run through a boring preselection process again.

Bob and I had a Mexican stand-off all night. The cut-off period was about 11 o'clock on a Sunday night. Bob played the greatest game of poker that has ever been seen that night. He obviously knew that I was going to put in the appeal. I kept ringing him and saying, `Bob, I won't do it unless you do it, too.' He said, ` No, I'm quite happy for there to be an appeal but you do it, young man. I'm not going to put it in.' Basically, it was left until about 10 minutes before the cut-off time when I finally jumped in my car and drove to Bob Harris's house. In fact, I was sitting at Chilla Porter's house making last minute calls, trying to get Pikey to be a co-signatory to the appeal. Of course, he had me totally sussed and was not part of it.

We both presented ourselves for preselection and history records that Max Evans won it again. Max has gone on to be the Minister for Finance in the Court government, and I am still a backbencher in opposition over here. Mind you, there was one bonus in that whole thing: I have saved myself from sitting on the back bench of the upper house in Western Australia for 10 or 11 years. So more power to Max!

Again, it was a good experience. Having been through that process with Bob of going through the preselection, we did get a lot closer. The next thing that came up was the Stirling federal division preselection in 1987. Bob was the president of the Stirling division. Again, he had left parliament. He had not left the party. He had not run off with his tail between his legs and ignored the party. He worked very hard within the Stirling division and within the northern suburbs generally and became the president of the division.

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the indulgence of the chamber. The Stirling preselection was another traumatic period in my life because I won the preselection, with a lot of assistance from Bob Pike on the ground organising the numbers. At that time, the President of the Liberal Party was Keith Simpson, who was certainly no friend of mine or Bob Pike's, and he was determined to ensure that I did not get that preselection.

PARA.TAB: We fought an extremely bitter fight during that period leading up to the July 1987 election. The president, Keith Simpson, tried every trick in the book and, in fact, got a legal opinion from a renowned Labor lawyer to say that the branches that were mine were not entitled to vote and, of course, that preselection was overturned. I record, for the first time in public, the incredible support that Bob Pike gave me during that incredibly traumatic time.

The next period when we worked together was during the 1990 Senate preselection which saw me arrive in this place. Bob, as an exquisite understander of the politics and also the feelings of the organisation, not only helped me with a lot of work in the branches, but also helped me craft my preselection speech. We decided, since I was the 14th speaker out of 15 applicants, that it should be a very brief speech. We put together a very punchy little 4 1/2-minute speech to the preselectors, which clearly impressed them.

The next indication of some of Bob Pike's philosophical commitments was through one of the first bills that I had something to do with when I arrived in this place, and that was the Australian Securities Commission legislation. Bob had been campaigning against a centralisation of the corporations power for a couple of years before that. I worked very closely with Bob on that legislation. People will recall—even though those opposite will not have appreciated what happened—that Bob was quite instrumental in ensuring that the Legislative Council in Western Australia was the only parliament in Australia to defeat the mirror legislation to make Western Australia part of the new Australian Securities Commission centralised corporate scheme. That caused some headaches for a while, but it was a stand on a very good principle.

Some of the things that Bob deserves to be thoroughly recognised for were his work—a lot of senators would recognise this work—in establishing a very powerful and effective committee system in the Legislative Council in Western Australia. It was somewhat of a surprise to me to know that the committee system in that place was not particularly effective. Bob, when he re-entered parliament at the 1989 election, worked very vigorously to set up a whole series of standing committees, very similar to the legislative standing committees which we have in this place. He did some very good work in establishing those committees, but also, more notably, in establishing select committees that investigated some of the more notorious WA Inc. dealings, which, in the end, one could only say were most instrumental in ensuring that public pressure built up so that there just had to be a royal commission. Even though that was a very costly expense, I think it was a process that needed to be gone through because we hope that it will be a long time before a government does the sorts of dealings that the Burke and Dowding governments entered into. Bob's children and Bob's widow, Patti, can be very proud of the contribution he made there.

In the short time remaining to me, I want to make some quite specific comments about Bob's work in the organisation because he did have some very special skills. One of those was something that very few politicians ever do; that is, actually to go out and sign up members. Some people who are detractors of Bob's and mine, and even Senator Crichton-Browne's, would describe the work that Bob did as branch stacking. Effectively, what Bob did was to go out on Saturday afternoons, Sunday mornings and at odd times through the week, knock on people's doors, present himself as a Liberal and ask people to join the Liberal Party. He was very successful at that. Bob Pike and I, probably in about the first month I was in the Senate, went out to a suburb called Hazelmere, which is near Guildford and not a particularly affluent area, but a suburb with some very nice people in it. It is an area where one would not expect a lot of success—

TALK.START.PARA: —It used to have even better people living there when I lived there.

—On a Sunday morning, Senator McMullan, one would not expect a great hit rate when knocking on people's doors asking them to join the Liberal Party. I went out and knocked on doors for about two hours. I came back to Bob at the appointed meeting time and he said, `How many have you got?' I said, `I have two. How many have you got, Bob?' He said, `I have got 17.' I said to Bob, `I had better come along with you and learn your technique.' I will not record the technique that Bob used, but it was a well practised routine, a sales routine he had crafted and developed over many years. When Bob Pike, Noel Crichton-Browne and Ian Campbell go out door knocking on Sunday mornings—which I am sad to say will never happen again—Bob always managed to get 30 or 35 people. I will not report my scores or Noel's, but they were never quite as good as Bob's.

PARA.TAB: I have probably treated this matter a little flippantly but I felt that that experience was important. Indeed, all political parties need to have a broad base of membership. There are very few ways of getting that unless one has paid field officers or shop stewards in unions carrying out that task. It is extremely good for politicians to get out on the streets. I am not just referring to doorknocking at election times, but getting out and asking people to join one's party. I always enjoyed going out on the street doorknocking with Bob seeking membership. It was an educational exercise in itself and I will treasure that experience for the rest of my life. It was very much grassroots politics that Australia has long since left behind. My training from Bob will put me in good stead for years to come.

I wish to record for the Senate some of the Pikeisms that I will cherish for the rest of my life. He had some classic sayings with which to greet people. During the Stirling preselection row, and even during my preselection in 1990 when I was successful, he would always be part of the team. When somebody put up their name for preselection, Bob would get on the phone and say, `Ian, I want you to know that you can ring me at any time after five in the morning until midnight any night. I will always be there to help you.' The next morning I would ring him at 5.00 a.m. and could hear him coughing and spluttering at the other end of the phone, but he would always be there to help you. No matter when you rang him, Bob would say, `Top of the morning to you, Pike speaking.' That is something we will never enjoy again.

Also when we were dealing with complex internecine politics in the Liberal Party, running through various ideas as to how to roll somebody from a branch or how to get somebody installed, Bob would say, `Let's go slow'—let us slow the conversation down. The next thing he would say was, `Let's put our think caps on.' These are some gentle little Pikeisms that I want to record for posterity.

The other one is that Bob would ring up with some crucially sensitive information and would say, `This is a Bob to Ian conversation.' I was never quite sure what that meant. Obviously it meant not to tell anyone else. I suspect that when Bob said, `This is a Bob to Ian conversation' he really meant to say, `Don't tell Noel.' Sometimes when one was rattling off one's thoughts to Bob and getting a little ahead of him, he would say, `Let me tell you before you tell me.'

In the closing moments of these remarks, I want to put on record Bob's great influence on the Liberal Party, particularly the Liberal Party of Western Australia, and on me personally. No matter how unpopular the cause, he was never afraid to nail his colours to the mast. He would never shillyshally around, but would always make sure that everyone understood his position and would reason it through in an articulate fashion. Bob would ensure that people knew exactly where he stood and the philosophic and principled basis of his belief. He was always keen to speak to his opponents and understand where they were coming from; also to ensure that they understood where he was coming from.

Bob Pike was a very great man. Many senators opposite would not have believed in a lot of what he believed in. Many people from the other side from Western Australia had a great respect for Bob. He made an enormous contribution to the WA Liberal Party and cannot be replaced. Bob has left a wonderful wife and seven children, who were very lucky to have enjoyed the time they had with him. It is very sad that we lost such a great Western Australian, and indeed a great Australian, late on Anzac Day 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to give a brief response to the government's white paper, with particular emphasis on my portfolio responsibilities of industry, trade and regional development. I remind the Senate that the white paper began life as an industry statement which was to be provided by the then minister for industry, the Hon. Alan Griffiths. However, a sandwich shop got in the way and we got this white paper.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats welcome many of the measures on employment, training and income support set out in the white paper. These will give help—which is only about a decade overdue—to the victims of long-term unemployment. But where are the other two strategies? There are bits and pieces of industry measures, some quite good, and several of the best have been taken from Australian Democrat policy statements. This signals the fact that a little light might be dawning on the government that it cannot just rely on the economic recovery to deal with Australia's problems. However, the government's policy contains no strategic framework and important components of a coherent industry policy are nowhere to be found. The employment, training and income support measures are a short-term bandaid. But our long-term structural problems require major surgery and the government refuses to pick up the knife.

The so-called regional development strategy is worse. It is regional development on the cheap. At $10 million it is an insult. Those parts of regional Australia devastated by the government's destruction of core industries through its level playing field stupidities of the past decade suffer the highest rates of unemployment, much higher than the cities, and have also the highest rates of long-term unemployment and the worst indices of social dislocation in the country. They deserve support. What have they got? `Fix it yourself' says the government. I will return to this disgraceful treatment of regional Australia later.

First, I will address myself to industry policy. On Wednesday last week in the Australian, Professor Heinz Arndt wrote that deficiency in aggregate demand was no longer a major factor in causing unemployment. The problem, he says—and I believe he is correct—is structural not cyclical. Despite this, the only strategy the government has in the white paper is to argue that the growth from our current recovery is the solution.

Professor Arndt cites as primary causes of unemployment the loss of jobs in labour intensive industries to newly industrialising countries; the replacement of labour by technology; job shedding in the name of micro-economic reform. The government has not addressed these structural problems in any coherent way. Last week's entirely predictable $660 million blow-out in imports is just more evidence of that failure.

The Australian Democrats believe that structural problems require structural solutions. Our policies address all three of the structural problems identified by Professor Arndt. Innovation is the key, as correctly identified by the white paper. But having identified this, there is only token and piecemeal support for developing an innovative Australia.

We welcome those measures that were included in the white paper. I refer to reducing the expenditure threshold for the R&D tax concession, which was a Democrat proposal. The measure relating to small business networking and increased funding for CSIRO and other research agencies were again policies that we have been pressing for. There is also support for commercialisation of high technology developed by small firms; and extension of the export markets development grants scheme to the tourism industry, although it is a little miserly to allow only a 25 per cent grant for tourism, which is one of our major growth industries.

All these measures are good, but they are not comprehensive and do not comprise a coherent strategy. If innovation is the key, we should have a national innovation strategy that identifies and addresses all the constraints to innovation and product development. This requires a comprehensive approach to developing the appropriate education base, providing facilities for research and development, access to venture and development capital and a strategic vision of the direction of change. These measures are a central component of new growth theory which has been developed in the Chicago University by, among others, Professor Reich who is currently President Clinton's adviser on industrial relations.

The ideas that we have put forward in our 1994 budget proposals and recent industry statement do address the structural causes of unemployment faced by Australia and do point the way to a coherent strategy to address this problem. We address the bias against labour in the tax system by proposing the phase-out of payroll tax, and tax incentives to small business to employ new staff. We recognise the role of small business as the engine of new job growth through a range of measures—some titbits were indeed picked up by the government—such as a proposal for the establishment of a small business loans insurance cooperation, and proposals for reform to company tax collection arrangements for small business. We have proposed a return to quarterly tax collection, no company tax payments for companies with incomes below $400,000 before September each year and a reduction in the uplift factor for provisional tax.

Why has the government not adopted these measures? The loss of jobs must be addressed and we must start in our labour intensive, import competing industries. We need a two-year pause in tariff reductions. We need better small business access to the export markets development scheme by reducing the expenditure threshold. We need packages of assistance targeted to industries needing transitional assistance, or to get new industries up and running. We need a $10 million pilot venture capital development fund to provide equity to new small businesses. We require superannuation funds to invest one per cent of their portfolios in venture capital and research and development syndicates.

Improving the economy and providing jobs for people who are now out of work starts with consumers. What we should now be concentrating on—and I signal a strong emphasis on this for the next 12 months by the Democrats—is a strong `buy Australian' campaign. It would include a review of labelling laws and reforms that would allow Australians a real choice to support their own industries by knowing clearly what sort of product they are buying. We will be looking to the government to implement even more actively and more positively the Bevis recommendations on government purchasing, and we will be looking for tougher anti-dumping measures. We have proposed these measures and we will be pushing them during the next 12 months in the context of a strategic view of industry needs. It is rather sad that the government has not provided that sort of vision in its white paper.

The third structural cause of unemployment identified by Professor Arndt is the loss of jobs through so-called micro-economic reform. Government business enterprises criminally have shed over 80,000 staff over the past three years. It is time to recognise the government's own role as an employer. It is about time that labour productivity gains in the public sector were used to expand services instead of cutting staff. It is time that public sector enterprises were again run for the benefit of the community rather than mindlessly privatised and sold for a song, as the government intends to do in the case of AIDC. It is time we started seeing an increase in public infrastructure spending from its current 40-year low to provide the services and structure needed by industry and by regional Australia.

The Australian Democrats, by contrast, have proposed a $1.2 billion program of rebuilding Australia's neglected infrastructure. Why has the government not addressed this cause of structural unemployment? The blind faith in market forces and level playing field fantasies that have dominated the government's thinking for the last decade make it clear why it somehow manages to believe that it is efficient and that it has been Australia's single largest job shedder. We have put forward a comprehensive strategy that addresses the structural problems of our industry. The most important features of that strategy are a commitment to innovation and a recognition of the lesson from our international competitors that targeted government assistance based on industry plans agreed between workers, industry and government is the way to develop competitive industry.

The recession has hit regional Australia much harder than urban areas. Core regional industries have been decimated by government policies. Unemployment rates are at 18 per cent in small towns which are shrinking, and government services are being cut with them. Young people are leaving for the cities and social dislocation, including suicide rates, is rife.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Wednesday the government brought down a document called Working Nation—its white paper on how to solve the problems of unemployment in this country. This was supposed to be another of Paul Keating's great policy initiatives but, in reality, it continues in the long line of failed policies in the area of unemployment over the last 11 years of this government. When we recall those particular initiatives such as One Nation, all the May economic statements and all the budgets, we find that they have failed to deliver anything like a proper employment level in this country. Yet the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) says that this is the one that is the panacea, this is the one that by the year 2000 will reduce unemployment in this country by five per cent. It will have to work a lot better than the previous ones.

PARA.TAB: I want to focus on one aspect of that white paper, an area which surprisingly was buried way towards the back of the paper. Given all the hype that was around about what was going to be done by this government for rural Australia, it is absolutely amazing that it got such scant attention. We had to look very hard at the white paper to find anything of any great significance for regional Australia.

It seems as though what the government has decided finally is that fixing the problems of regional Australia is going to be so time consuming and costly that, really, it will not bother at all. But look at the problem that we have. We have an unemployment rate in this country of 10.3 per cent, but in the regional areas of Australia we find this figure skyrockets. In the Hunter region we have 16.1 per cent unemployment. It is higher in Newcastle at 16.4 per cent. The north coast of New South Wales in my area has long, persistent and entrenched unemployment levels of 17 per cent. What hope is there in this paper for people in those areas, the ones who have heard of the Kelty report, the ones who put in submissions? A large amount of time and effort was put into compiling a document and making recommendations that this white paper was supposed to address.

It was, to me, a great pity that the press did not focus, as it often does not do, on the failures of this government. It looked at the general treatment of unemployment, but I saw very little attention paid in the press to what is one of the most pressing needs in this country, and that is solving the problem of unemployment in regional Australia. The government set up a task force to do it, but the net effect of what the task force has done is to not deliver for the people of rural and regional Australia.

What did regional Australia get out of the $6.5 billion over four years? It got $270 million over four years across the whole of regional Australia. Yet as the McKinsey report found, 41 per cent of the regions covered in the rural areas are in terminal decline. In effect, what the government has done in this report—and the Prime Minister not only admits it; he almost boasts about it—is to let it go and pass the buck over to the local authorities. Honourable senators will recall that in his speech he cited two regions. He talked about Goulburn Valley and Sunraysia and what was being done in the northern areas of Victoria. He outlined the government's plans and talked about the doubling of product in those areas. But it was not because of anything he was doing; it was because of the efforts of the local authorities.

If we look at the nature of the programs in areas like Sunraysia, we realise that what they are really on about in those areas is desalination. If the salt problem in these areas can be got rid of, it will boost productivity enormously straightaway. So the Prime Minister is giving a very misleading impression in the one example that he cited.

What is the role of the federal government in all of that? It plans to put in a few capital works to back up what the local authorities are doing. I would have thought that since the time of Federation, and even in the times of the colonies, it was seen as the natural role of government to put in capital works to back up local initiatives. In other words, this white paper is doing absolutely nothing for regional Australia. As a matter of fact, the figure of $270 million across the whole of regional Australia over the next four years is probably showing that the government is drawing resources out of regional Australia, not putting extra into it. It was all too hard for the government, so in effect it has given up on regional Australia.

Let us see what the government has done for one of the major problems in rural Australia, that is, transport. The white paper provides $10 million in 1994-95 and then $20 million over the next three years—$70 million completely for infrastructure in response to what the Kelty report saw as probably the major initiative that was needed in regional and rural Australia. This is what it provides.

One of the most amazing things, in light of what has happened so far, is that the government's main response seems to be to set up another committee. It has decided to create the national transport planning task force—another committee. We have had the Kelty report, the McKinsey report and the Industry Commission report and, as a result of all those exhaustive findings, what does the government say? It says, `We will set up the national transport planning task force'—anything to avoid spending money on these regions and doing anything about the real problem.

The government did not really need to set up another report because the McKinsey report identified that all levels of government need to be involved in proper labour market reform, in deregulating transport, in improving infrastructure and in minimising red tape. We did not really need a government report to tell us that—we have known that for years—but the government has again squibbed it and done nothing about it.

The government has decided to bring in one measure which we realise, when we have a close look at it, is really just part of the old, failed One Nation package. It has recycled what it was going to do in investment with pooled development funds and infrastructure bonds. It is trying very hard to make these more attractive to investors. It has not worked so far, and the government is going to try to make it slightly more attractive. Whether that succeeds, we will see.

Regional Australia has major problems. The government, in this white paper, has really just thrown a pittance at those problems. We will be reminding the people of regional Australia of this right up until the next election.

SPEECH.PARA: The remainder of Senator Spindler's speech read as follows—

PARA.TAB: The Government has had four inquiries into regional development over the past year. The Industry Commission said that the Government needed to make regions more attractive to capital by improving regional infrastructure. The McKinsey Report said that business had real concerns about Government commitment to infrastructure. The Kelty Report proposed dozens of needed infrastructure projects worth hundreds of millions of dollars.

So what did we get? $10 million this year for two `demonstration' projects. Now the Australian Democrats pushed very hard for, and support the two projects in Goulburn Valley and Sunraysia. However, this picture of regional Australia launching into a boom based on thousands of people coming from all over Australia to be inspired by what's happening in Mildura and Echuca is not one that gives me a lot of confidence.

Bill Kelty called for a commitment to equal access to basic infrastructure for all Australians, with special assistance to remote areas—an admirable set of goalposts, but the government seems to be kicking the ball in the other direction. Why has the Government so completely dumped the results of the Kelty Report?

The Government is relying, it claims, on the private sector to build regional Australia's infrastructure. The history of private sector support for regional infrastructure would suggest this belief ranks slightly ahead of a belief in the Tooth Fairy and slightly behind the Easter Bunny. Of course, the Government will claim that this fantasy can be made reality through the bit of tinkering it has done to the tax-breaks on infrastructure bonds.

We welcome the changes to the infrastructure bonds. We hope they work. But there are two fundamental flaws in this approach. The private sector doesn't build the sort of infrastructures communities need, because most of the benefits from a lot of infrastructure are social and not capturable by private industry. The private sector is never a great provider of schools, hospitals, and community services, and doesn't have that much better a record in provision of transport infrastructure. The other problem with the approach is that it doesn't recognise that the reason the private sector doesn't like major infrastructure projects isn't the return—it's the risk. If the Government is really serious about generating private involvement in infrastructure, it at least needs to look at some Government equity or insurance against completion risks.

Apart from the breath-taking lack of support for regional infrastructure, what else did we get? The Democrats support the financing for Regional Economic Development Organisations, but without support for infrastructure projects, their effectiveness will be limited. We also support the Regional Environment Employment Program. But that's about it, really.

We had called for a $50 million package to maintain Government services in hard-hit rural areas. Where is it? We had called for a 12-month extension to the Investment Allowance for rural producers—where is it? For years the injustice of rural families not being able to get access to assistance such as Basic and Family Payments because of the paper value of the family farm has been well documented. We called for the exemption of the family farm from the assets test. The failure of the Government to act on this proposal is nothing less than heartless.

And the most amazing gap of all is that there is not one mention in the entire White Paper of the higher costs faced by country dwellers for petrol and other basics. Did the Government put together a regional development package without visiting the regions? It's pretty hard to talk to anyone outside of metropolitan Australia without finding out that these price disparities are about the single biggest issue on their minds.

The Australian Democrats recognise the benefits of vibrant regions—diminished pressures on urban infrastructure, national security, a more varied lifestyle choice for all Australians, benefits for tourism, niche business opportunities and many more. Vibrant regions are therefore an appropriate social goal and, as a nation, we have to recognise that we have to pay to achieve that goal. As part of that, we have proposed general acceptance of the principle of cost-equalisation between city and country for basic items such as petrol, communications, water and electricity. For yesterday's Government White Elephant—sorry White Paper—we called for immediate action to reduce city/country petrol price disparities. What happened? Why no action?
So we've got bits and pieces of an industry strategy and a so-called regional development plan that is an insult and a disgrace. When is the

SPEECH.PARA: Government going to muster the courage and intellectual rigour to develop a coherent, strategic approach to industry policy and regional development?

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The UN Security Council, in a letter to the UN Secretary General dated 20 September 1993, expressed deep disappointment that an agreement had not been reached in talks based on the Secretary-General's Set of Ideas, and called on the Turkish Cypriot side to give its support to the effort to secure an agreement on the package.

(2) The Security Council's comments were based on a report submitted by the Secretary-General, in which he expressed disappointment that Turkish Cypriot leader Rauf Denktash had both failed to promote acceptance of the package of Confidence Building Measures after New York talks were adjourned in June 1993, and failed to return to the talks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Government is aware that a number of Australian citizens were expelled from their properties in northern Cyprus after the Turkish invasion in 1974.

Most claims lodged by this category of persons, and which could be verified by production of a title deed, have now been settled. Property claims by persons of Greek or Greek Cypriot extraction, or with any Greek or Greek Cypriot links (such as Greek financing of the original purchase), have not been accepted by the Turkish Cypriot administration. While Australian citizens in general are not targeted for special treatment, citizens and residents of Australia of Greek or Greek Cypriot extraction are denied access to the north, as are residents and citizens of other countries of Greek or Greek Cypriot extraction. The question of granting legal aid to Australian citizens, whether citizens at the time of the Turkish invasion or not, is one more appropriately directed to the Attorney-General. A comprehensive negotiated settlement based on the UN Secretary-General's Set of Ideas and which makes provision for the recovery of or compensation for property expropriated, rather than litigation, remains the best hope for those Australian citizens dispossessed in 1974.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 8 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the report on serial sponsorship relating to mail order brides:
(1) What is being done by the department to specifically implement the recommendations pertinent to the department.
(2) What performance indicators are being used to assess the effectiveness of those implementations.
(3) What changes, if any, have been made to the recording and identification process for those involved in serial sponsorship.
(4) How are prospective brides alerted to the identity of a person known to have been involved in serial sponsorship.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The report referred to, Serial Sponsorship: Immigration Policy and Human Rights (the Iredale report), was a consultancy report commissioned by my department and issued by the Centre for Multicultural Studies, University of Wollongong. Based on input from community groups and other interested parties and following consultation with the Attorney-General's Department and the Privacy Commissioner's Office, my department has prepared advice that I am currently considering as the basis of the Government's response to the Iredale report. I expect to be in a position to announce the Government's response in the near future.
(2) Performance indicators will be developed as part of the implementation plan following the Government's response to the Iredale report.
(3) I am considering my response to the Iredale report and these issues will be addressed in that context.

(4) A Sponsorship for Migration to Australia form (form 40) requires a sponsor who has previously sponsored a prospective spouse to provide certain details of previous sponsorships. This information is available to prospective spouses who must lodge the sponsorship form with their migration application.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 22 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it a fact that, prior to June 1990, overseas students were issued visas to attend courses at Australian institutions only on the basis of accepted enrolment at education institutions accredited with the Department of Employment, Education and Training; if so, what conditions were placed on these visas and what monitoring was undertaken by the department to ensure compliance with these conditions.
(2) What conditions or requirements are, and have been, placed on education institutions which enrol overseas students for courses in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The criteria used for approving or rejecting full fee paying students were set out in my response of 23 March 1994 to Question Number 1039. Enrolment at educational institutions accredited with the Department of Employment, Education and Training (DEET) was only one of the requirements to be met.
The following conditions were placed on student visa holders prior to June 1990:
not to seek authority to settle in Australia and to depart from Australia on completion of studies or expiry of student temporary entry permit;
satisfy course requirements and maintain a valid enrolment; and
not work for more than 20 hours per week while the course is in session.

The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs (DIEA) relied on advice either directly from educational institutions or through DEET concerning students who no longer were attending classes or making satisfactory progress. The Department wrote to these students advising them to depart Australia. Students were asked to provide evidence of departure details. Compliance action was also taken against individuals located as a result of general compliance activity such as visiting places of employment where a breach of student visa conditions occurred.
(2) This is a matter for DEET and State and Territory Governments.
